body.p: Charleston, S. C. 12 Elul 5613.
Rev. I. Leeser, Philadelphia.

Dear Sir! Your kind
letter of the 6th inst. was duly received, and my answer
to it must be a apology, for not having sent, as
yet, the conclusion of the article 'On the philosophy &c.
Suffering, for nearly 3 weeks, with ulcers, so much so,
that I was confined to my bed, and could not even attend
to my ministerial duties, I was utterly unable, to finish
the translation of the little work. Were it worth the while
to publish a portion of the balance, I would do send you
that part: A portion would not do, and the whole a I
could not finish,—in as much as,—besides my sickness, I am
so much occupied in my preparations for the holidays, that it
is impossible to me, to accommodate you this month. Being
as you well know, but one year in the ministry, and this, too,
in a Portuguese Congr., I have to study all chaunts
for the coming holidays, and to prepare no less than 11
sermons for one month,—besides all this—
my approaching marriage occupies also somewhat
my mind. Still, for the Nov. Number of your Occ.
you shall have the paper, as I work at it by fits
& starts.

Your requests, expressed in your last, shall be
most faithfully complied with.

Things are going on here in the old smooth way,
but I would inform you of the following facts, relative to
the NOrleans sufferers.—

As soon as an appeal was made here by the
papers, the members of my Congregation contributed to the general fund,
“handsomely & liberally,” without being induced by a Charity sermon,
which I do not approve of, as previous observations have taught me,
that they never result in the wished for success, unless, we adopt—
as Dr. Raphall has done, lately, the plan of calling the names
of every one present, and thus causing him, to proclaim loudly
the amount he is willing to contribute,—a process most improper,
illiberal & uncharitable. Rev. Jacobs adopted the delivery of a
Charity Sermon, and failed, for the contribution amounted only to $81,
which was afterward increased by private subscription, to
the round sum of $100. But, instead of remitting this sum to the
our distressed fellow Israelites, these orthodox men sent it to the
newspaper-Office, as “a first collection,” for which, of course,
they received a sublime puff. We acted otherwise. As soon
as the appeal from the Jews reached us, Col. Jacobs & my humble self, although sick went about
on Friday the 25 ult., after returning from a funeral, and within two
hours time we had collected the amount of $115. Had we not
thought it proper to send the money forthwith, according to the rule:
“give cito dat, bis dat,” and were not so many of my Congr.
absent, or had we received the appeal 8 days before, the sum
would at least have been 5 times larger. Rev. Jacobs, not
wishing to remained behind me, again delivered, last Sunday,
a Charity Sermon, which had been advertised during the whole week, in
all city-papers, and the amount collected, reached only
about $60. it must also be remarked, that at least 2/3
of both the collections at Rev J's. Synagogue, were contributed by
members of my Congr. Present at the Occassion—He following
letter was received on the 6th Sept.
New Orleans Sept. 1. 1853.
Col. Meyer Jacobs, Charleston S. C.

Kind & Respected Sir! I have the pleasure
to acknowledge, through the hands of our esteemed mutual friend,
Mr. Columbus Moise, the receipt of a draft for $114.43, in-
tended for the relief of suffering Israelites, during the dreadful
epidemic now prevailing. This evidence, that our un-
fortunate brethren are sympathized with, nerves and enables
us to continue our exertions for their speedy relief, and al-
though we feel humiliated & humbled at the necessity that
existed for appeal to our kindhearted friends abroad, a double
gratification is the result in the exhibition of fraternal love,
and noble generosity on your part, and the visible & cheering
benefits, arising from your assistance in relieving the distressed
who are in want.

Please make to those, who contributed so promptly,
our kindest acknowledgement, and for yourself be pleased to
receive our special thanks for the pains you have been put to,
in making the necessary arrangements, so punctually to trans-
mit it.I am very truly,
Your obt servt
David C. Labatt.
On Sept. 9. we read in the Charleston Courier:

We were gratified also, to perceive from New-
Orleans, that the amount of $115, less the exchange, had been
remitted to that city for the relief of the suffering Israelites
there on the 25 ult. by the members of Hasell Str. Synagogue
of this city; (The congr. of Reformed Israelites.) which fact had

not been communicated to us, otherwise we should at once
have done them the justice, of chronicling their prompt action
on the occasion, more especially as the members of this con-
gregation had already contributed so handsomely, through
us to the Howard association”—

I communicate to you these facts &
papers, in order to do justice any Congr. & myself,—and
hope, you will give notice of them in due time.—

I conveyed your respects to Miss Rachel,
and she requested me to return them to you, as she
knows you very well. Our marriage will take place on
Hebrew 26 Oct. next. According to our
time-hallowed custom I wish you Hebrew
remain truly yours
